content.rendered:
whoo,

my son (9) and his friends play it too. We have limited media time, a total of half an hour during the week and a little more on the weekends.
Minecraft is a very creative game, like Lego, only on tablet/pc/console.

My son and his friends play together in a world on wifi and build a settlement there together with the coolest buildings and structures. I’m really impressed how creative they are there. My son has z. B. a house in the shape of a giant duck (no idea how he came up with that ) built, three-dimensionally completely anatomically correct and hollow inside with rooms. On the duck’s legs, a ladder leads inside, and from the eyes you can go to the crook, which is a balcony.

Yes, the game is designed to make you want to keep going because there’s always something to build. Actually, most computer games are such that you always want to complete another round or another level. That’s why I think you have to learn and practice how to deal with it.

By the way, with my son and his best friend, Minecraft also leads to a lot of creativity in real life. They would like to create a Youtube channel with Minecraft Lets Plays and have been planning this for months. They design logos and they write scripts and whenever they meet I see them scribbling and doing and doing…

Of course they are too young to really do that, even legally. But they really have a lot of fun just planning it. If there is ever a video (I’ve already been asked for help using video editing software), it will be duly appreciated in the family circle, but will not be published.
